content: The "Protecting Our Children Comes First Act of 2007" emphasizes the grave danger faced by abducted children and the need for coordinated efforts among local, state, and federal law enforcement agencies to address the issue. Growing numbers of children are victims of child sexual exploitation, often involving new technology like the Internet. Children can be separated from parents during disasters. Sex offenders are a threat. The Office of Juvenile Justice administers programs to prevent offenses against vulnerable children and support missing children's organizations, including the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children serves as a national resource center and works in partnership with various law enforcement agencies to find missing children and prevent child victimization. It operates a national network linking with missing children clearinghouses in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and international organizations like Scotland Yard and INTERPOL. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children collaborates with law enforcement agencies globally to locate missing children and prevent child victimization. It operates a national network connecting with missing children clearinghouses in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and international organizations like INTERPOL. The Center receives grants to operate a 24-hour toll-free telephone line for reporting missing child information and coordinating reunification procedures. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children operates a toll-free telephone line to coordinate with the national communications system, runs the official national resource center, and provides information on services and programs for missing and exploited children and their families. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children coordinates programs to locate missing children, disseminates information on beneficial programs, and provides annual reports on missing children to the Department of Justice. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children provides guidance on identifying missing children through school records and birth certificates, offers technical assistance and training to various agencies in preventing and addressing cases of missing and exploited children. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children assists in locating missing and exploited children nationally and internationally, provides analytical and technical support to law enforcement agencies, offers on-site technical assistance in child abduction cases, and provides forensic technical assistance in identifying deceased children. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children assists in identifying unidentified deceased children through facial reconstruction, tracking attempted child abductions, training law enforcement on locating non-compliant sex offenders, deploying the National Emergency Child Locator Center during disasters, and operating a cyber tipline for reporting child sexual exploitation online. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children works on identifying deceased children, tracking attempted abductions, training law enforcement on finding sex offenders, deploying the Child Locator Center during disasters, and operating a cyber tipline for reporting online child sexual exploitation, including possession, distribution, and enticement of children for sexual acts. They collaborate with law enforcement, Internet service providers, and others to reduce the distribution of inappropriate images on the Internet. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children focuses on reducing the distribution of inappropriate images of sexually exploited children on the Internet. They operate a child victim identification program to help law enforcement agencies identify victims of child pornography and other sexual crimes. Additionally, they develop and disseminate programs on child abduction prevention, sexual exploitation prevention, and internet safety to various groups. The funding for these efforts has been increased to $40,000,000 for fiscal year 2008. SEC. 4. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 408(a) of the Missing Children's Assistance Act is amended to allocate $40,000,000 for fiscal year 2008 and necessary funds for fiscal years 2009 through 2013. SEC. 5. REPEALER. The Missing Children's Assistance Act is amended by removing section 407 and renumbering section 408 as section 407.
